quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Streaks is the most impactful feature. We have, right now, over 9 million users with a year plus streak. If you look at the numbers, I think it's been our biggest growth lever.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Strong data-backed claim that a single retention mechanic can be a primary growth lever at massive scale.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: What Duolingo really focuses on is, how do we help users build habits around language learning? Getting user come back the next day is the biggest problem to solve.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Frames retention as habit formation and identifies next-day return as the core problem to optimize for.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I'd say test everything, we've run in the last four years over 600 experiments on the streaks, so every other day.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: high-velocity experimentation as a sustained operating model for improving retention features.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We used to say continue, our standard CTA is continue, and we changed that to commit to my goal, and it was a massive win.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Concrete example of how small copy changes can materially shift user motivation and outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Say that you played a mobile game, or that you've done it for 3,000 days in a row, I don't know, maybe that hits a little bit different than you've learned Spanish for 3,000 days in a row.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Counterintuitive insight that framing and identity (what users think they’re doing) can change the emotional impact of the same streak metric.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Tired of bouncing around multiple tools to uncover what's really happening inside your product?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the practical pain point of fragmented tooling and the value of consolidating product insights in one place.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Pendo makes it easy to answer critical questions about how users are engaging with your product, and then turn those insights into action.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concise product-analytics-to-action loop that practitioners can use as a guiding principle for instrumentation and iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: First, Pendo is built around product analytics, seeing what your users are actually doing in your apps so that you can optimize their experience. Next, Pendo lets you deploy in-app guides that lead users through the actions that matter most. Then, Pendo integrates user feedback so that you can capture and analyze what people actually want.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a clear three-part methodology (behavior analytics → guided actions → feedback) for improving product experience.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And the new thing in Pendo, session replays, a very cool way to visualize user sessions.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Points to a concrete technique—session replay—for diagnosing UX issues beyond aggregate metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I'm not surprised at all that over 10,000 companies use it today.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific adoption data point that signals market validation and widespread applicability.

quotes.topic_title: What streaks are and why they matter
quotes.text: So, I have right now over 9 million users with a year plus streak.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A concrete data point that quantifies the scale of long-term habit formation driven by streaks.

quotes.topic_title: What streaks are and why they matter
quotes.text: Streaks are a great engagement hack. I'm of the opinion that any team, any app out there can introduce a streak, and if you figure it out, it probably works to retain users, but at the core, you have to have an app that people want to use, and people really like using Duolingo.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A practitioner takeaway: streak mechanics amplify an already-desirable core product rather than substituting for it.

quotes.topic_title: What streaks are and why they matter
quotes.text: And so, not only is it itself, us iterating on the streak a huge driver of DAUs, but it's also something that enables other really high valuable features.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A product strategy framework: treat streaks as a platform/primitive that powers other systems (e.g., notifications, challenges).

quotes.topic_title: What streaks are and why they matter
quotes.text: We think about growth just as much as bringing new users onto the platform is not losing them.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A memorable reframing of growth as retention-first, useful for setting priorities and metrics.

quotes.topic_title: What streaks are and why they matter
quotes.text: So, we have these things called streak freezes, it's like insurance for your streaks.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A practical design pattern: build flexibility into habit mechanics to reduce drop-off from inevitable missed days.

quotes.topic_title: Origins: XP-based streaks to one-lesson streaks
quotes.text: But I'd say one of the most impactful experiments we ran was about, this was actually as I was joining, or just after I joined we had run this experiment, was to move it from a XP based streak to just do one lesson a day, and you'd extend your streak.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A concrete example of simplifying a retention mechanic by changing the streak requirement to the smallest meaningful daily action.

quotes.topic_title: Origins: XP-based streaks to one-lesson streaks
quotes.text: And we saw none of that. This was a huge driver of DAUs, just making it easier to extend your streak, but I think really importantly it's still meaningful.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Counterintuitive result: lowering the bar didn’t reduce perceived value and materially improved daily active usage.

quotes.topic_title: Origins: XP-based streaks to one-lesson streaks
quotes.text: The unit of use, and as you're thinking about building a streak, I think it's really important to think about what the unit of use of your app is.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A reusable framework for designing streaks around the product’s core repeatable action rather than abstract goals.

quotes.topic_title: Origins: XP-based streaks to one-lesson streaks
quotes.text: It's always easy as a PM to have a million goals or objectives for what you want your feature to be and potentially build a more complex feature, and a one lesson streak, it's just easy for more users to understand.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Practical product advice: resist complexity and optimize for clarity and comprehension to broaden adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Engagement vs learning: the Duolingo philosophy
quotes.text: No question, everything we do is focused on engagement because you won't learn anything if you're not coming back to the app.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A clear philosophy that prioritizes engagement as a prerequisite for learning outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Engagement vs learning: the Duolingo philosophy
quotes.text: I see myself as a learning PM as much as an engagement PM, because the easiest way not to learn on Duolingo is not to come back the next day.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Reframes retention work as core to learning impact, not separate from it.

quotes.topic_title: Engagement vs learning: the Duolingo philosophy
quotes.text: if we don't make the app retentive, you will have no opportunity to engage with our learning features.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Actionable product logic: retention is the gateway metric that enables downstream value delivery.

quotes.topic_title: Engagement vs learning: the Duolingo philosophy
quotes.text: if you start to dumb down, and honestly this is something we wrestle with the streak as well, you start to dumb down the experience, and your users aren't actually learning, they're not going to care.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Warns against over-optimizing engagement mechanics in ways that erode real user value and long-term retention.

quotes.topic_title: Engagement vs learning: the Duolingo philosophy
quotes.text: we make sure that as we're making changes to the streak, we're not hurting the learning experience
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A practical methodology: guardrail learning outcomes while iterating on engagement features.

quotes.topic_title: Testing extremes and building experimentation muscle
quotes.text: Duolingo has very much, has a strong test it philosophy, we're willing to test a lot of different... Honestly, we'd much rather test it than debate it for days and days.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A clear experimentation-first operating principle that prioritizes rapid learning over prolonged internal debate.

quotes.topic_title: Testing extremes and building experimentation muscle
quotes.text: What we realized when we ran this experiment is DAUs moved not one bit.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A concrete example of an intuitive retention tweak (making streaks easier) failing to move the core metric.

quotes.topic_title: Testing extremes and building experimentation muscle
quotes.text: Nobody thinks about, oh, I just want to come do one question on Duolingo, nobody thinks about that.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A memorable warning about choosing the right “unit of measure” for habits—optimize for meaningful user intent, not trivial actions.

quotes.topic_title: Testing extremes and building experimentation muscle
quotes.text: we've run in the last four years, over 600 experiments on the streaks. So, every other day effectively-
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A striking data point illustrating the velocity and scale of Duolingo’s experimentation muscle.

quotes.topic_title: Testing extremes and building experimentation muscle
quotes.text: If we're adding something and it's neutral, we tend to shut it down because it's just more cognitive load, it's something that we're going to have to start building around, a new UI element that we have to figure out how it fits into our system.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A practical decision rule for experiment outcomes: neutral results often aren’t worth the complexity cost.

quotes.topic_title: Experiment decision-making: neutral results and complexity
quotes.text: So, the first is focusing on the zero to seven day user experience.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A clear retention framework: prioritize the earliest window where behavior change is most leverageable.

quotes.topic_title: Experiment decision-making: neutral results and complexity
quotes.text: And I would say this is, if you look at whatever our breakdown of experiments are, we run definitely more than average number of experiments on getting users to go from a zero to seven day streak.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Actionable experimentation strategy: overweight tests that move users through the first-week activation milestone.

quotes.topic_title: Experiment decision-making: neutral results and complexity
quotes.text: And a lot of this is because we've looked at the data for our retention curves, and what we found is that once you get to seven days, loss aversion kicks in, and you retain.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A data-backed behavioral mechanism (loss aversion) explaining why a 7-day streak is a key retention inflection point.

quotes.topic_title: Experiment decision-making: neutral results and complexity
quotes.text: So, going from a one to a two-day streak, huge jump in retention, two to three day streak, slightly less but still huge and it's up until day seven.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Specific retention gradient insight: the biggest gains come from early streak progression, not later streak lengthening.

quotes.topic_title: Experiment decision-making: neutral results and complexity
quotes.text: Once you hit day seven, it flans out.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway: after day 7, additional streak length yields diminishing retention returns.

quotes.topic_title: Optimizing the first week: loss aversion threshold
quotes.text: So, the first is focusing on the zero to seven day user experience.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A clear retention framework: prioritize the first-week experience as the highest-leverage window for habit formation.

quotes.topic_title: Optimizing the first week: loss aversion threshold
quotes.text: And a lot of this is because we've looked at the data for our retention curves, and what we found is that once you get to seven days, loss aversion kicks in, and you retain.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Connects a specific behavioral mechanism (loss aversion) to a measurable retention threshold (7 days).

quotes.topic_title: Optimizing the first week: loss aversion threshold
quotes.text: Once you hit day seven, it flans out.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway: retention gains flatten after day 7, so optimizing beyond that may have diminishing returns.

quotes.topic_title: Optimizing the first week: loss aversion threshold
quotes.text: Rather than design the big complex feature for V1, just do the simplest encapsulation of what that feature can be, see if it has legs, and then just add to it iteratively over time, this is partially how we get to 600+ experiments on streaks, they're not all big ones.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A practical experimentation methodology: start with the smallest testable version, validate impact, then iterate—enabling high experiment velocity.

quotes.topic_title: Streak goals: commitment, optionality, and friction
quotes.text: Rather than design the big complex feature for V1, just do the simplest encapsulation of what that feature can be, see if it has legs, and then just add to it iteratively over time, this is partially how we get to 600+ experiments on streaks, they're not all big ones.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A practical experimentation methodology: start with the smallest testable version, then iterate to scale learning velocity.

quotes.topic_title: Streak goals: commitment, optionality, and friction
quotes.text: And so, we started with that, and I think it was like you're seven times more likely to finish the course if you have a 30-day streak, and just that message when you started your streak, I telling you that, was awesome. Huge win.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A concrete example of outcome-framed messaging (“7x more likely”) driving behavior without changing the underlying product mechanics.

quotes.topic_title: Streak goals: commitment, optionality, and friction
quotes.text: And this was a fascinating one because it was a good win to give users that easier goal, to try to capture them before they said no, but it was almost just as big a win to add that opt out button.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Counterintuitive finding: adding an opt-out (seemingly reducing engagement) can increase commitment and overall performance.

quotes.topic_title: Streak goals: commitment, optionality, and friction
quotes.text: And I'm a huge fan of testing way too many arms for an experiment, just to be able to isolate your hypotheses, but we captured just what happens if we add an opt-out button, and adding an opt-out button... And you would think, as a PM, oh, now users might not engage with my feature, that's a bad thing, but it was a huge win to let them do that.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Actionable experimentation advice: use multi-arm tests to isolate mechanisms, and don’t fear optionality if it increases intentional commitment.

quotes.topic_title: Streak goals: commitment, optionality, and friction
quotes.text: we realized that yes, we could speed users through the screen more by virtue of picking a goal for them, but that act of selecting, I think it's 30 days, I think it's 14 days, was where we were getting so much of the engagement from this feature.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A lesson on “good friction”: forcing an explicit choice can outperform optimization for speed and defaulting users into a recommendation.

quotes.topic_title: Mining for wins: hypotheses, cross-team learnings, copy tests
quotes.text: So, I'd say it's rare that we go into something where it's just like, let's just try something. Typically, we have some insight because of all of these experiments that we've run, that hey, if we do this, I don't know, it's one here, or it's worked here, it's driven this user engagement, if we massage that and try in this scenario, or a different screen, we come in at least with a strong hypothesis of this will work.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A clear methodology for experimentation: reuse prior learnings and enter tests with a strong hypothesis rather than random iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Mining for wins: hypotheses, cross-team learnings, copy tests
quotes.text: A lot of times we do look, and we're like, a lot of the apps that we look at actually are games themselves, so it's like, all right, you're playing Royal Match, or there's the new Pokemon trading card game that I'm spending way too much time on, you look at these games and see what they're doing, and it's really good fodder for what we can do.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A practical source of product ideas: borrow engagement mechanics from top-performing games and adapt them to your context.

quotes.topic_title: Mining for wins: hypotheses, cross-team learnings, copy tests
quotes.text: With copy, for instance, we've actually set up really good infrastructure for copy testing. I'm of the opinion that companies should run, as long as you have the user base to do it, copy test constantly.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Actionable advice to invest in copy-testing infrastructure and treat copy as a high-velocity experimentation surface.

quotes.topic_title: Mining for wins: hypotheses, cross-team learnings, copy tests
quotes.text: Going back to that goal screen, we used to say Continue, our standard CTA is Continue, and we changed that to Commit To My Goal, and it was a massive win.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A concrete example of a “tiny” copy change producing outsized impact, reinforcing the ROI of systematic copy testing.

quotes.topic_title: Mining for wins: hypotheses, cross-team learnings, copy tests
quotes.text: And copy changes are so cheap, it's just you translate, for us, we have a lot of users all over the world, and a lot of UI languages, but just come up with a bunch of ideas, translate some strings...
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A cost/benefit framing for experimentation: copy tests are low-cost to run even in multi-language products, so you can iterate broadly.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding a Frankenstein product: reviews and resets
quotes.text: For me it's like, if you have a clear strategy where your feature is going, hopefully all of those A/B tests are not just done to get some cheap gain, they're done with a long-term goal in mind.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A practical principle for keeping experimentation aligned to a coherent product strategy rather than chasing incremental wins.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding a Frankenstein product: reviews and resets
quotes.text: It's easy to do, and in some sort of awful local maxima, if you're not constantly looking at your roadmap and you don't have a clear strategy.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A memorable warning that constant micro-optimization can trap teams in a local maximum without periodic strategic review.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding a Frankenstein product: reviews and resets
quotes.text: we do this with the streak at least on a quarterly basis, to look at, okay, well, what have we learned, how has our streak developed, and how do we imagine this going in near future?
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A concrete operating cadence (quarterly) for stepping back from experiments to assess learnings and direction.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding a Frankenstein product: reviews and resets
quotes.text: eventually you just hit a local maxima, and you say, you talked about launching neutral experiments, this is a great example, where it's like all right, cool, now we need to throw a bunch of this stuff out, based on all the learnings, can we reset this real estate, can we reset this UI, reset this feature, in such a way that is just as good as what we have now but is way more plain or simple, that we can, again, start to layer on?
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A counterintuitive methodology: periodically “reset” an over-optimized UI to a simpler baseline so you can iterate cleanly again.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding a Frankenstein product: reviews and resets
quotes.text: Those are really hard experiments to get to win obviously, because they are so optimized, but they're really important to do, otherwise, yeah, you just end up with a kitchen sink of a feature.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Highlights why simplification/reset work is difficult to justify via A/B tests yet essential to avoid incoherent, bloated features.

quotes.topic_title: Why streaks work: meaning, framing, long-term progress
quotes.text: I do think though that is contingent on companies who are going to figure out if a streak works for them, to figure out how can you frame the streak in such a way that a user does feel good about it.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A practical framing principle: streaks only work if you can make the behavior feel affirming and meaningful to the user.

quotes.topic_title: Why streaks work: meaning, framing, long-term progress
quotes.text: And it's easier for a Duolingo, but I think there's creative ways to phrase this for users.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Encourages teams in less inherently “meaningful” categories to still design streaks by creatively positioning the value to users.

quotes.topic_title: Why streaks work: meaning, framing, long-term progress
quotes.text: the streak works really well for Duolingo because with language learning it's really hard to see day-to-day progress in becoming more fluent.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A mental model for when streaks are most effective: when real progress is slow and not easily observable day-to-day.

quotes.topic_title: Why streaks work: meaning, framing, long-term progress
quotes.text: Duolingo makes it easier, but you still got to put in thousands of hours if you're going to reach C1 or C2 fluency, and that is really hard to track on a day-to-day, and so the streak works really well for us because we might not be able to tell you, hey, you now know 0.01% more Spanish, but we can show you, hey, you've gotten your streak a little bit higher.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A concrete example of substituting an unmeasurable micro-progress metric with a tangible proxy (streak length) to sustain motivation.

quotes.topic_title: Why streaks work: meaning, framing, long-term progress
quotes.text: I think this works particularly well when you're an app that is doing something that's going to be sensed or felt over a longer term to help contextualize that progress in a way that makes more sense, or at least feels more tangible to a user.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Generalizable guidance: use streaks to “make progress tangible” for long-horizon outcomes that users can’t immediately feel.

quotes.topic_title: Clarity drives retention: explaining streak mechanics
quotes.text: We've realized over time that a lot of users do not understand how a streak works, and it can be as small as, well, I don't understand how streak freezes work, or I don't... Like my mom the other day was talking to you about it, she's like, "Oh, I didn't use Duolingo and I come back and my streak's still there."
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Highlights a common retention pitfall: even “obvious” mechanics are frequently misunderstood, so clarity is a product lever.

quotes.topic_title: Clarity drives retention: explaining streak mechanics
quotes.text: I ran some tests that just tried to in eight words explained what a streak was, that was it. And it was a massive win because it really dumbed down here is exactly how the streak worked, and it really helped users just understand what they needed to do.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A concrete methodology: test ultra-simple explanatory copy to improve comprehension and retention without building new features.

quotes.topic_title: Clarity drives retention: explaining streak mechanics
quotes.text: I think it was in the order of magnitude of over 10,000 DAUs for us, and actually, maybe a small bit of context. So, Duolingo really cares about the metric CURR current user retention rate
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Provides a specific impact data point and anchors it to a key retention metric (CURR) practitioners can adopt.

quotes.topic_title: Clarity drives retention: explaining streak mechanics
quotes.text: test copy 1000 different ways, sometimes it's not the big beautiful feature that's going to drive the huge gains, sometimes it's just something simple as a few words.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Counterintuitive product lesson: small copy changes can outperform major feature work, so iterate aggressively on messaging.

quotes.topic_title: Clarity drives retention: explaining streak mechanics
quotes.text: a lot of what I'm looking for is for us to have a better day 14 impact than better day one impact because it means that users are retaining better over time.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A practical evaluation framework for retention experiments: prioritize longer-horizon lift (e.g., day 14) over short-term spikes.

quotes.topic_title: When a winning experiment shouldn’t ship
quotes.text: And it won, the hypothesis was a good one. But we realized, and I remember having this conversation with Luis, is like, cool, this is our most important screen in the app, it is our lesson, it is where users learn, and the focus here is on learning.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A reminder that even winning experiments can be rejected if they compromise the core purpose of the product’s most critical surface.

quotes.topic_title: When a winning experiment shouldn’t ship
quotes.text: And now you've added this other thing up there that could be distracting for users.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Highlights the practical tradeoff between engagement mechanics and cognitive focus in a “sacred” user flow.

quotes.topic_title: When a winning experiment shouldn’t ship
quotes.text: And I think the question, we talked about roadmaps and strategy here, the question that he had for me, and I didn't have a good answer for at the time, was like, so what else are you going to do with this? What's your iteration ideas? Where's this going to go?
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A reusable decision test: don’t ship a change unless you can articulate its strategic direction and iteration path.

quotes.topic_title: When a winning experiment shouldn’t ship
quotes.text: And what we realized is that, honestly, it was just an easy engagement win idea, but we had touched our most sacred space in the app to do that.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: A concrete example of resisting metric-driven “easy wins” when they erode the integrity of the core experience.

quotes.topic_title: When a winning experiment shouldn’t ship
quotes.text: And so, that was a case where it's like, yeah, it was a nice win, but we'd added that UI element, and at least at the time it was less clear what we would do with it and we realized that long term it was just going to get in the way, and we'd rather, for simplicity's sake, pause that, shut it down, and keep the lesson to be a little bit of learning sanctuary it was.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Shows a disciplined methodology: prioritize long-term UX coherence and simplicity over short-term metric gains.

quotes.topic_title: Design and cultural considerations: flame vs number
quotes.text: We did some UXR in India many years ago, and this was something that just did not resonate at all there, which was a really interesting learning.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Concrete example that a core metaphor (the streak flame) can fail in specific cultural contexts, underscoring the need for global research.

quotes.topic_title: Design and cultural considerations: flame vs number
quotes.text: And I think that as you're thinking about designing around a streak, don't get too caught up into what is this the beautiful story that you're trying to tell, at the expense of it being a really comprehensible feature.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to prioritize comprehension over clever narrative when designing retention mechanics.

quotes.topic_title: Design and cultural considerations: flame vs number
quotes.text: And so, as you're thinking about product design, making that product design a clear distillation of this is what we're actually tracking, form should follow a function here, was a learning for us.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Memorable design principle/mental model for aligning UI with the underlying metric or behavior being tracked.

quotes.topic_title: Design and cultural considerations: flame vs number
quotes.text: Clarity also doesn't have to come at the expense of delight.
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Counterpoint to the common tradeoff framing—suggests you can design for both understanding and emotional payoff.

quotes.topic_title: Design and cultural considerations: flame vs number
quotes.text: And so, think about the screen holistically, but every single thing that you're doing on the screen, how can you use it to communicate what is the point of this feature? How does it work?
quotes.speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
quotes.context: Practical methodology for evaluating each UI element by how well it teaches the user the mechanic and purpose.

quotes.text: Coda combines the best of documents, spreadsheets, and apps to help me get more done, and Coda can help your team to stay aligned and ship faster by managing your planning cycle in just one location, set and measure OKRs with full visibility across teams and stakeholders, map dependencies, create progress visualizations, and identify risk areas.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Outlines an end-to-end operating model for execution—centralized planning + OKRs + dependency mapping + progress/risk visibility.
